message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs of virilization, including mild facial hair and clitoromegaly, and absence of the uterus and ovaries suggests a disorder of sexual development. Among the options, only 5-α reductase deficiency can cause female external genitalia with male internal genitalia. Sex chromosome monosomy would result in Turner syndrome with an absence of ovaries and estrogen deficiency, but wouldn’t produce male internal structures. 21-hydroxylase deficiency would cause ambiguous genitalia, but not male internal structures. Complete androgen insensitivity would result in a female phenotype, without virilization or absence of the uterus and ovaries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of uterus and ovaries suggests a disorder of sexual differentiation. The presence of clitoromegaly and mild facial hair suggests excess androgen production. Among the options, only 5-α reductase deficiency leads to excess androgen production with ambiguous genitalia, but female internal reproductive organs. Sex chromosome monosomy (Turner syndrome) would result in primary ovarian failure and short stature. 21-hydroxylase deficiency would lead to variable degrees of virilization and salt-wasting. Complete androgen insensitivity would result in female phenotype with no uterus or ovaries, but normal external genitalia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of uterus and ovaries, normal male level of testosterone, and external genitalia with clitoromegaly suggest a 5-α reductase deficiency. This disorder impairs the production of dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which leads to incomplete masculinization of the external genitalia in individuals with XY karyotype.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of the uterus and ovaries suggests a condition known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome (MRKH). Among the options, only 5-α reductase deficiency can cause both clitoromegaly and MRKH. Sex chromosome monosomy (such as Turner syndrome) can cause absence or partial development of the ovaries but not clitoromegaly. 21-hydroxylase deficiency can cause ambiguous genitalia but not absence of the uterus and ovaries. Complete androgen insensitivity can cause absence of the uterus but not absence of the ovaries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of uterus and ovaries and the presence of clitoromegaly suggest that the patient has androgen insensitivity. Among the options, only 5-α reductase deficiency causes ambiguous genitalia with both male and female characteristics. This can lead to a lack of female internal organs and delayed menarche.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s external genitalia and absence of the uterus and ovaries suggest 5-α reductase deficiency. This condition results in the inability to convert testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, which prevents the development of male external genitalia and the formation of the internal female genitalia. Facial hair and clitoromegaly occur due to increased testosterone levels. Sex chromosome monosomy (Turner syndrome) would result in the absence of the ovaries and underdeveloped female external genitalia. 21-hydroxylase deficiency would result in ambiguous genitalia and primary adrenal insufficiency. Complete androgen insensitivity would result in normal female external genitalia and no uterus, but pubic hair would be absent or sparse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of facial hair, clitoromegaly, and coarse pubic hair suggests high levels of androgens. Absence of uterus and ovaries suggests a disorder of sexual development. Among the options, 5-α reductase deficiency is most likely because it results in decreased conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, leading to ambiguous genitalia in individuals with XY chromosomes. Sex chromosome monosomy would result in Turner syndrome, which does not present with high androgen levels. 21-hydroxylase deficiency would result in ambiguous genitalia in individuals with XX chromosomes. Complete androgen insensitivity would lead to a lack of androgen action and would not present with high androgen levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of a uterus and ovaries suggests that the patient has androgen insensitivity syndrome. However, the presence of mild facial hair and clitoromegaly suggests that the cause is 5-α reductase deficiency, which impairs the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, leading to ambiguous genitalia and delayed or absent puberty. Sex chromosome monosomy and 21-hydroxylase deficiency may cause similar symptoms, but do not present with an absence of uterus and ovaries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of uterus and ovaries along with mild facial hair and clitoromegaly suggest 5-α reductase deficiency. Sex chromosome monosomy would result in Turner syndrome which is associated with ovarian failure and short stature. 21-hydroxylase deficiency would cause ambiguous genitalia and virilization but the patient would still have a uterus and ovaries. Complete androgen insensitivity would result in a female appearance with absent pubic hair and a shallow vagina.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of the uterus and ovaries suggests a genetic male. Coarse and curly pubic hair extending to the inner surface of both thighs, clitoromegaly, and mild facial hair suggest virilization. 5-α reductase deficiency causes virilization in genetic males due to the inability to convert testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, leading to incomplete male genital development and ambiguous external genitalia. Sex chromosome monosomy, 21-hydroxylase deficiency, and complete androgen insensitivity are all associated with different types of intersex disorders, but do not present with the specific virilization pattern seen in this patient.
